title: How to Eat Smoked Salmon

steps.headline: Make scrambled eggs and salmon.
steps.description: The number of eggs you should scramble will depend on how many people you want to feed. Scramble 2 per person. Make the scrambled eggs in a hot pan. Then cut a bagel in half and toast it. Drape a slice or two of salmon over each bagel half and then top with the scrambled eggs. You can also cut 2 slices of smoked salmon into bite-size pieces and add them to the scrambled egg mixture before you cook it.

steps.headline: Add smoked salmon to eggs Benedict.
steps.description: Toast 2 halves of an English muffin. Lay a slice of smoked salmon on each half. Then top each half with a poached egg and spoon a spoonful of hollandaise sauce over the top. You can season the eggs with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Make smoked salmon avocado toast.
steps.description: Mash ½ an avocado in a small bowl until it’s mostly smooth (a few chunks are okay). Brush some olive oil onto 2 slices of sourdough bread and set them on a cooking sheet. Place the sheet in a 350° F (177° C) oven and toast for 5 minutes. Divide the avocado between the 2 slices of bread and top with the smoked salmon and a dollop of sour cream.

steps.headline: Top sliced cucumber with smoked salmon and brie cheese.
steps.description: Cut ½ of a wheel of brie cheese into chunks and layer them into the bottom of oven-proof skillet. Bake the skillet at 375° F (191° C) for 10 to 12 minutes until the cheese is bubbly. Add 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) (0.5 ounces) capers, ¼ cup (2 ounces) finely diced scallions, and 1 minced clove of garlic to the cheese and mix it well. Then bake it for another 2 to 3 minutes. Slice 3 cucumbers into 8 pieces each. Top each slice with a spoonful of cheese mixture and top with a small slice of salmon.

steps.headline: Add smoked salmon to a baked potato.
steps.description: Slice 2 baked potatoes down the middle. Fill each potato with 1 full slice of smoked salmon, 2 spoonfuls of tomatoes, and a dollop of sour cream. Season with salt and pepper if you like.

steps.headline: Top crusty bread with salmon.
steps.description: Tear a loaf of warm crusty bread into chunks. Drape thin slices of smoked salmon, slightly bigger than the chunk of bread, over each chunk. Then top with a dab of sour cream and a pinch of black pepper.

steps.headline: Make rye and salmon squares.
steps.description: Cut rye bread slices into 2 inch (5 cm) squares. Spoon ½ teaspoon of horseradish onto each square, and then top with a thin slice of salmon. Garnish with dill.

steps.headline: Serve simple smoked salmon.
steps.description: Cut each slice of smoke salmon into 1-inch (2.5 cm) strips. Squeeze fresh lemon juice over each strip and then add black pepper to taste. Roll each strip of salmon up and then spear it with a toothpick.

steps.headline: Toss smoked salmon with pasta.
steps.description: Cut 2 slices of smoked salmon into small, bite-size pieces. Boil your favorite pasta and then drain. Toss the pasta with the salmon, fresh herbs, lemon juice, and a dollop of crème fraiche.

steps.headline: Add salmon to your favorite salad.
steps.description: Fill a bowl with spinach or your favorite greens. Add bite-size pieces of smoked salmon, fresh peas, and thin slices of red onion to the salad. Add 2 teaspoons of your favorite dressing and toss the salad.

steps.headline: Make smoked salmon cakes.
steps.description: Peel and dice 2 medium potatoes. Bring them to boil in a pot of water. Lower the heat and simmer until the potatoes are soft. When the potatoes are cool, add ½ cup (4 ounces) chopped smoked salmon, 2 tablespoons (29.6 ml) (1 ounce) of mayonnaise, and ½ teaspoon lemon juice to them and mix with a fork. Form the mixture into 3-inch (7.5 cm) patties. Dip each patty in a whisked egg, then in panko bread crumbs. Bake the cakes for 8 minutes in a warm skillet with 2 tablespoons (29.6 ml) (1 ounce) of oil in the bottom, flipping halfway through.

steps.headline: Keep the salmon in the original packaging.
steps.description: If you’re not going to use the salmon right away, keep it in the original packaging. It should come vacuum-sealed, which will keep the fish fresher longer.

steps.headline: Wrap opened salmon tightly in plastic.
steps.description: If you do open the package to use some salmon, wrap the remainder tightly in plastic wrap. Make sure it’s wrapped tightly enough to prevent air from getting in. If air does get in and the edges get dry and flaky, just cut that part away with a sharp knife.

steps.headline: Refrigerate unopened salmon for up to 2 to 3 weeks.
steps.description: If you’ve already opened the salmon, it should stay fresh in your fridge for a week.

steps.headline: Freeze the salmon for up to 3 months.
steps.description: As long as you keep your smoked salmon in its original packaging, you can keep it in the freezer for up to 3 months. If you open the salmon and want to freeze part of it, put the remainder in a freezer-proof bag.
